title: Tanks Forever Home (Doggie Daycare Set 2)
features: Tank is a bullmastiff named for his great size. At least, that was the name Shawn and Kat gave the gentle giant after they found him behind the bookstore. The kids convince their parents to let them foster the stray while animal rescue looks for his owner. Meanwhile, Shawn and Kat try to figure out how such a loving dog could come to be lost. What will happen to Tank if Shawn and Kat cant help him find his forever home? Doggie Daycare is open for business. Join siblings Shawn (9) and Kat (7) Choi as they start their own pet-sitting service out of their San Francisco home. Every dog they meet has its own special personality sending them on fun (and furry) adventures all over the city!
description: GR 1–3-Siblings Kat and Shawn are back in a new installment of the Doggie Daycare series. While passing by a bookstore with friends Sasha and Mitchell, they encounter a stray bullmastiff behind a dumpster. With some help from Stella, who works at a nearby animal rescue, the foursome brings the dog back to the shelter and names him Tank. Kat and Shawn then find the perfect home for Tank with an elderly neighbor named Mrs. Tanaka, who lives alone and misses a Great Dane she used to have. The siblings are conflicted when the dog's caretaker, Mr. Nguyen, turns up. Luckily for them, Mr. Nguyen is unable to give Tank the attention he needs, and Mrs. Tanaka is able to adopt the dog after all. The book is designed with large type and features a racially inclusive cast of characters: Kat and Shawn are Korean American (as is the author); Sasha and Mitchell have brown skin and black hair; Mr. Nguyen and Mrs. Tanaka are of unspecified Asian heritage; and Stella is white. While full pages of text and selected vocabulary may challenge some emergent readers (e.g. "assisted living", "responsibility", "disappeared"), the book may be a good choice for fans of series like Katie Woo or King and Kayla who are ready to take the next step in their reading. Black-and-white spot illustrations accompany the text and are rendered in a wide-eyed cartoon style. VERDICT This warm, sweet story is sure to please young dog lovers.—Lauren Strohecker, McKinley Elem. Sch., Elkins Park, PA

Carol Kim lives in Texas with her husband, two daughters, and one very well-behaved dog. Her childhood was spent in Southern California, where she grew up eating kimchi every day. She writes both fiction and nonfiction for children. When shes not writing, she enjoys reading, cooking and traveling, and exploring food from different cultures.
